docs.lead_paragraph: Gloria Belisle is probably not the kind of patient doctors had in mind when they first envisioned treating medically underserved people from afar with high-technology diagnostic tools. Like any patient receiving such care in rural America, Mrs. Belisle, who has congestive heart failure, does not generally see the medical practitioners following her condition. Instead, twice a day she sits in front of a computerized machine that asks, ''How can I help you?'' It then proceeds to measure everything from her blood pressure to her heart rhythm.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. James De Yarman specializes in performing hair transplants at his clinic in San Diego. Last September, he took his expertise on line, setting up a site on the World Wide Web called DrPropecia.com. There, he offers information about the drug Propecia, which promotes hair growth in men. Prospective patients can fill out an on-line medical history form, which Dr. De Yarman reviews for a $50 fee. If he determines that the drug would be useful for a patient, he then prescribes it and sells it to him. ''I have to assume they're telling me the truth,'' he said. ''I'm not a drug store. I look at this as providing a service, going on line to sell it. What would I do different if they were to come into the office?''

headline.main: Dispensing Of Drugs On Internet Stirs Debate

docs.lead_paragraph: Ralph Benedetto is dying in his mobile home in Clearwater, Fla. Swirling around him is a debate over whether he and patients like him should be denied liver transplants that might save their lives -- specifically, whether the nation's health care system denies transplants out of failure to keep abreast of medical and technical advances or out of eagerness to save money.

headline.main: Of Life, Death and the Rules of Liver Transplants

docs.abstract: Ralph Benedetto is among those at center of debate over whether people with hepatitis B should be denied liver transplants that could save their lives; Benedetto contracted hepatitis B 10 years ago from blood transfusion; his doctors say he could now die without liver transplant, but his health maintenance organization refuses to pay for treatment; it cites guidelines issued by state of Florida recommending against liver transplants to hepatitis B patients on ground that virus would destroy replacement liver just as it did the original; Federal guidelines that apply to 39 million Medicare recipients say same; medical researchers and liver transplant surgeons claim advances in treatment of hepatitis B make those guidelines outdated; experts say there is now wide agreement that hepatitis B, in and of itself, is no longer valid reason to deny someone liver transplant; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Promoters of a hot new exercise machine make a profound claim: a four-minute workout that really works. The assertion comes in an infomercial from Time Works for a $600 device that works the upper and lower body with twisting and stepping motions. Though such a less-is-more approach -- four minutes, four times a week -- seems hard to fathom, the Time Works infomercial and Web site prominently feature an as yet unpublished study conducted at Adelphi University in Garden City, N.Y. Researchers compared increases in fitness levels of two sedentary groups of subjects who worked out four times a week. One group exercised for 4 minutes per session on the Time Works machine and another group exercised for 20 minutes per session on a treadmill with an upper body component.

docs.lead_paragraph: For Kristie Wolek, the trouble started about a year ago, when her periods became so heavy that the blood loss made her severely anemic. She was exhausted all the time. The problem was caused by four fibroids, benign tumors in her uterus that had been tiny and harmless for more than a decade but had recently begun growing rapidly. Two doctors recommended a hysterectomy, an operation to remove the uterus and the only sure cure for fibroids. Though Ms. Wolek, 43, did not want to have more children, she did not want a hysterectomy, either. But she thought she had no choice.

headline.main: A Less Invasive Alternative for Fibroids

docs.lead_paragraph: Video and computer games that teach children how to live with asthma or diabetes are becoming so popular that some health care providers are now covering their purchase price, and the United States Health Department is seeking to expand their use. Click Health, a Silicon Valley firm, is credited with developing two interactive software products -- ''Bronkie the Bronchiasaurus'' and ''Packy and Marlon'' -- to help children with diabetes or asthma take care of themselves.
